51 Vita sancti Cuthberti.
SEint Cudbert was i-bore : here in Engelonde.
god dude for him gret miracle : ase &yogh;e schulle under-stonde.
Þe &yogh;wyle þat he was a &yogh;ong child : and in is ei&yogh;teteoþe &yogh;ere,
With &yogh;ounge children he pleide atþe bal : þat is felawes were.
Þare cam gon a luyte child : hit ne þou&yogh;te þreo &yogh;er old,
A swete creature and fair : milde it was and bold;
to þe &yogh;onge Cudbert he &yogh;eode : "leue broþer," he sede,
"Ne þench nou&yogh;t on swuche idele games : þanne dost þou a guod dede."
Seint Cudbert ne tok none &yogh;eme : to þe childes rede,
And pleide forth with his felawes : ase huy alle him bede.
Þo þis &yogh;ongue child i-sai&yogh; : þat he is red for-sok,
A-doun he feol to grounde : and gret deol to him tok,
And bi-gan to weopen sore : and his hondene forto wringue.
Þe children hadden alle deol of him : and bi-lefden heore pleiingue,
huy gladeden him ase huy couþen : sore huy gonne to siche;
And euere made þis &yogh;oungue child : reulich deol i-liche.
"A weilawei," þis Cudbert seide : "&yogh;wi weopest þou so sore?
&YOGH;if we þe habbez ou&yogh;t mis-don : we ne schullen none more."
Þanne spac þis &yogh;ounge child— : for sore huy weopen bei&yogh;e,
"Cuthbert," he seide, "it ne falleth þe nou&yogh;t : with &yogh;ongue children to plei&yogh;e;
None swuche idele games : ne bi-cometh þe for-to wurche,
&YOGH;wane god hath i-porueid þe : on heued of holie churche."
With þusse worde men nusten : &yogh;wodere þat &yogh;ongue child i-wende—
An Aungel of heouene it was : þat ore louerd þudere sende.
Þo bi-gan[MS. bigan gan] seint Cudbert : to weope and siche sore,
And lette a-wei is idele games : þo nolde he plei&yogh;e more:
he made his fader and is freond : setten him to lore,
And in his &yogh;onghede ny&yogh;t and day : of-seruede cristes ore.
Þo he in grettore eolde was : ase þe bok us hauez i-seid,
hit bi-feol þat þe bischop seint Aydan : sone þare-Aftur was ded.
Cudbert a-felde was with schep : Aungles of heouene he i-sei&yogh;
Þe bischopes soule seint Aydan : to heouene bere an hei&yogh;.
"I-nelle schep wite," seint Cudbert seide : "fol ich am to longue,
Schep i-nelle wite none lengore nouþe— : a-fongue ho-so heom[al. om.] a|fongue."
he wende to þe Abbeye of Gireuaus : grei&yogh; monek he bi-cam—
gret Ioye mauden þe Monekes alle : þo he þe Abite nam.
Swiþe wel he is ordre heold : he was of grete penaunce,
Þe holieste monek he was i-holde : in engelonde oþur in Fraunce.—
hit bi-feol þare-aftur-ward : þat þare cam a goute
In is kneo, of Anguische gret : &yogh;ware-of he hadde doute;
So longue, þat is kneo to-swal : gret Anguysche he i-fielde,
Þe senewes in is hamme schronken : he ne mi&yogh;te þanne leg i-wielde,
Ne strechche forth is leg bi-neoþe : þat Ioynede to is þi&yogh;;
Ase a crupel lame he was—: he i-werth swiþe sori.
No man ne couþe him þare-of rede : þat is leg i-sei&yogh;;
Ake nathþeles euere was is hope : to iesu crist a-hei&yogh;.
In A day, solas for-to habbe : he liet him bere a-boute,
And in þe fielde he i-mette a wel fair kny&yogh;t : with loreins swiþe proute.
Þe knyt bad heom one stounde a-bide : þat seint Cudbert bere;
he bi-heold and handlede þane sore leg : ase þei he leche were.
"Nim," he seide, "þe milk of one kov : þat is of o colour,
Iuys of smal-Ache do þar-to : and clene &yogh;wetene flour;
Seoth it to-gadere swiþe wel : and leie it al hot þar-to,
A-brod ase þei hit a plastre were : and guod it schal þe do."
Þo he hadde þis i-seid : þe kny&yogh;t is wei forth wende—
An Aungel of heouene it was : þat ore louerd þudere sende.
Are seint Cudbert þe plastre hadde : longue, him þou&yogh;te,[om. him þou&yogh;te] to is legge i-bounde,
his leg and is senewes : bi-comen hole and sounde.—
hit nas nou&yogh;t longue þare-aftur-ward : ase þe bok us doth telle,
Þat þe Abbot sende him out : to one of heore celles;
hostiler he was þare i-mad : gistes to onder-fongue.
god dude fair miracle for him : are he hadde i-beo þare ou&yogh;t longue.
Aungles þare comen to him ofte : and with him huy ete
Ase þei it oþure gistes weren— : þe gistningue was ful swete!
gistes wel gladliche þene mete he &yogh;af : he nolde no man werne,
heom þat beden par charite : for he nas noþing stuyrne.
him-seolf he wolde &yogh;iue heom watur : to waschen with hire[r. here] hond,
And serui heom of alle þe mes : and bi-fore heom stonde.—
hit bi-feol þat an hiendi gist : and a wel fair þare cam
And bad þe mete par charite : and Cudbert In him nam;
watur to is hondene he him &yogh;af[al. largeliche] : and[om.] on þe hei&yogh;e deis him sette,
Mete and drinke he him &yogh;af : and with guod heorte it fette,
to þe bachouse he &yogh;eode him-seolf : ase þe bakares hadden i-bake,
hi[s] giste to fetten bred al hot : þe gladdore him for-to make.
Þo he cam a-&yogh;ein with þe hote bred : his gist ne fond he nou&yogh;t;
Þare-of hadde þis holie man : gret wonder in is þou&yogh;t.
Þicke snov&yogh; was þare-oute : he ne mi&yogh;te nou&yogh;t finde is fore,
&yogh;ware-forth he wende a-wei : in snowe ne in þe flore.
Ase he sou&yogh;te þeosne holie man : a[n] wende a-boute wel wide,
he smulde a suyþe swote smul : in a chaumbre þare-bi-side.
Þo he into þe caumbre cam : he fond a bord i-sprad,
And þreo loues þare-op-on al hote. : þo was he wel glad,
And seide, "þis was godes Aungel : þat hath þis hidere i-brou&yogh;t;
he cam hidere us for-to fede : and him-seolf ne beo i-fed nou&yogh;t."—
eche ni&yogh;te &yogh;wane þeos monekes : to bedde weren i-gone,
Cudbert wel stilleliche : wende him forth al one,
In-to þe colde se he &yogh;eode : a-non op to þe chinne;
For-to hit was midni&yogh;t nei&yogh; : so he stod þare-inne.
Þanne he wende up þare-of : and þo[al. whan] he cam to londe,
For feblesse he lai a-doun : he ne mi&yogh;te nou&yogh;t wel stonde.
Þanne comen þare op of þe se : tweie oteres wel grete;
Ouer-al huy lickeden þis holie man : are huy him wolden lete.
&YOGH;wane huy him hadden i-lickede so : huy wenden in-to þe se,
And seint Cudbert hol and sound : in-to is celle a-&yogh;e;
with oþure he &yogh;eode to matynes : &yogh;eorne he song and radde,
Þe Monekes wenden euer-echone : þat he come fram is bedde.
A monek þat þare-inne was : onder-&yogh;at it ech del,
Ake ase seint Cudbert him bad : he[MS. þat he] it for-hele[de][MS. for hele] swiþe wel.—
Ase ore louerdes wille was : þare-aftur it dude bi-falle
Þat þe bischop of Duyrham deide : al-so we schullen alle:
Men nomen þo seint Cudbert : and maden him bischop þere.
Swyþe wel he wuste is bischopriche : þat folk he dude wel lere.
þo was þat soþe to ende i-brou&yogh;t : þat þe Aungel him seide,
Þat he scholde an heued of holi churche beo : þo he atþe bal pleide.
þo he hadde god i-serued longue : aftur him he sende:
In þe Monþe of luyde : of þis worlde he wende
to þe Ioye of heouene. : and god us graunti al-so,
Þoru&yogh; þe bone of seint cudbert : þat we moten comen þar-to.
